Documentation¶

SplitP nx_tree¶

class splitp.nx_tree.NXTree(newickString, name=None, numStates=4, taxa_ordering=None)¶

A rooted phylogenetic tree.

A rooted phylogenetic tree consisting of a collection of node objects and an adjacency matrix

num_nodes¶

The number of nodes in the tree

num_bases¶

The size of the character set for the phylogeny

nodes¶

A list of node objects representing the nodes in the tree

adjM¶

An adjacency matrix describing the connections within the tree

initDist¶

The initial distribution of states/characters at the root of the tree.

add_node(n, branch_length=0, in_node=None)¶

Adds a new node to the tree

Parameters

  • n – The node object to add into the tree.

  • in_node – The name of the parent node, default is None and is used for the root.

draw_from_multinomial(LT, n)¶

Use a given table of probabilities from getLikelihoods() and draw from its distribution

flattening(split, table)¶

Build a flattening matrix from a split

Parameters

  • split – A string representing the split to build the flattening from

  • table – A pandas data-frame table with site pattern `probabilities’

Returns

A flattening matrix as a data-frame (to provide labels)

get_descendants(n, return_iter=False)¶

Returns a list of children/descendents of a given node

get_num_taxa()¶

Returns the number of taxa/leaf-nodes in the tree

get_parent(n)¶

Returns the parent node for a given node

get_pattern_probabilities()¶

Returns a full table of site-pattern probabilities (binary character set)

get_root(return_index=True)¶

Returns the root node

is_leaf(n_index_or_name)¶

Determines whether a node is a leaf node from it’s index.

is_root(n_index_or_name)¶

Determines whether a node is a root node from it’s index.

parsimony_score(pattern)¶

Calculate a parsimony score for a site pattern or split

Parameters

pattern – A string representing a site pattern or split

Returns

A parsimony score for the given split or site pattern

split_score(M, k=None, singularValues=False)¶

Returns the split score for a given flattening matrix

subflattening(Ft, specialState='T', type=(1, 1))¶

Creates a subflattening from a transformed flattening data frame

svd_error(M)¶

“Returns the SVD for a given matrix (All but two/four largest SVs)

to_xml()¶

Returns a string-representation of the tree

transformed_flattening(F, S=None)¶

Creates a transformed flattening from a flattening data frame

SplitP old_tree¶

class splitp.old_tree.node(mat=None, index=None)¶

Represents a node, used by the tree class.

index¶

The number of nodes in the tree

pars¶

The size of the character set for the phylogeny

inEdgeMat¶

A list of node objects representing the nodes in the tree

  • in_node – The index of the parent node, default is None and is used for the root.

SplitP parsers¶

splitp.parsers.newick_to_json(newick_string, namestring='id', lengthstring='branch_length', childrenstring='children', generate_names=False)¶

Parses a newick string (example “((A,B),C)”) into JSON format accepted by NetworkX

Parameters

  • newick_string – The newick string to convert to JSON. Names, branch lengths and named internal nodes accepted. If no names are given, an ID is generated for the name if generate_names=True.

  • namestring – The label for node name to use in the JSON (default “id”).

  • lengthstring – The label for branch length to use in the JSON (default “branch_length”).

  • childrenstring – The label for children arrays to use in the JSON (default “children”).

  • generate_names – Whether or not to generate names if none are given

SplitP tree_helper_functions¶

splitp.tree_helper_functions.frob_norm(m)¶

Calculates the Frobenius Norm for a given numpy array

splitp.tree_helper_functions.generate_all_splits(num_taxa, trivial=True, onlyTrivial=False, onlyBalance=-1)¶

Generates all splits as string-representations

Parameters

  • num_taxa – The number of taxa on the tree.

  • trivial – Whether or not to calculate trivial splits, default True.

  • onlyTrivial – Whether to ONLY create trivial splits, default False.

Returns

A list of string-representations of splits (using ‘|’-notation)

splitp.tree_helper_functions.get_balance(s, asTuple=False)¶

Returns a string formatted ‘X|X’ which describes the balance of a given split string
